case_vignette: A 53-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of intermittent severe left neck, shoulder, and arm pain and paresthesias of the left hand. The pain radiates to the radial aspect of her left forearm, thumb, and index finger. She first noticed her symptoms after helping a friend set up a canopy tent. There is no family history of serious illness. She appears healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. When the patient extends and rotates her head to the left and downward pressure is applied, she reports paresthesias along the radial aspect of her left forearm and thumb. There is weakness when extending the left wrist against resistance. The brachioradialis reflex is 1+ on the left and 2+ on the right. The radial pulse is palpable bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Neurology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been dealing with severe pain in my left neck, shoulder, and arm along with tingling in my left hand for the past three months.
Could you tell me your age and sex, please?
I am a 53-year-old woman.
Do you have any history of diabetes or high blood pressure?
No, there's no history of serious illness in my family.
Have you experienced any weakness in your left arm or any difficulty with your fine motor skills?
Yes, there is weakness when I try to extend my left wrist against resistance.
Have you recently experienced any trauma or injury to your neck or shoulder?
No, but I first noticed my symptoms after helping set up a tent.
Do you take any medications or have you undergone any recent medical procedures?
No, I have not mentioned any medications or recent medical procedures.
**Final Diagnosis:** Cervical Radiculopathy

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having severe pain in my left neck, shoulder, and arm, along with tingling in my left hand, for the past three months.
Do you have any medical conditions or take any medications that may be relevant to these symptoms?
No, there's no history of serious illness in my family, and I appear healthy.
Have you recently experienced any trauma or injury to your neck or shoulder?
Yes, I first noticed these symptoms after I helped set up a canopy tent.
Got it. Have you experienced any weakness in your left arm or noticed any changes in your grip strength?
There is weakness when I try to extend my left wrist against resistance.
Understood. Are you experiencing any difficulty with coordination or balance?
No, just the pain and tingling, and the weakness in my wrist.

Thank you. Based on your symptoms and the history of a recent physical activity, along with weakness in your left wrist, it's possible that you are experiencing symptoms of a condition known as cervical radiculopathy. This is often caused by compression or irritation of the nerve roots in the cervical spine (neck area). I would recommend seeking an evaluation from a healthcare professional for further assessment and management.
